title.narrative: Health Emergency Response to ensure life-saving primary and secondary healthcare services

description.narrative:
On August 15 the Afghan government fell and within days the World Bank paused funding to Sehatmandi while alternative funding channel decisions could be made. As an interim measure, the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, TB, and Malaria (GFATM) channeled funds through UNDP which cover the month of October. Thereafter, WHO and UNICEF are taking over the operationalization of the Sehatmandi project through CERF funding for a period of three months as the primary UN agencies with a health mission. This project sustains the delivery of BPHS and EPHS services, through the existing framework of the project, to the Afghan people as an emergency measure to avoid large-scale preventable morbidities and mortalities. With this funding, WHO and UNICEF support a combined 2,168 facilities across 31 provinces between November 2021 and January 2022.
UNICEF supports 1,038 Sehatmandi health facilities (1 RH, 8 PHs, 26 DHs, 316 BHCs, 450 HSCs, 190 CHCs, 12 MHNTs and 35 others) in 15 provinces (Badakhshan, Badghis, Ghazni, Ghor, Heart, Kandahar, Khost, Kunduz, Paktika, Zabul, Helmand, Nimroz, Paktya, Urozgan and Farah).
UNICEF and WHO are jointly exploring the most efficient and effective mechanisms and approaches to oversee, collaborate, and coordinate grant management to maximize cost and time efficiencies. UNICEF and WHO also use the national and regional structures to supervise and monitor the project implementation and engage external Third-Party Monitoring (TPM) teams to ensure accountability. Both agencies implement activities through the existing structures including working with the current UNDP/GFATM-funded, long-term recruited Sehatmandi NGOs in order to avoid the creation of a parallel system and facilitate the handing back of activities to the original channels.
